# Lowest temperature recorded on Earth

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Wostok-
Station_core32.jpg/300px-Wostok-Station_core32.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wostok-
Station_core32.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Wostok-Station_core32.jpg "Enlarge")

Aerial photograph of Vostok Station, the coldest directly observed location on
Earth.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/LakeVostok-
Location.jpg/300px-LakeVostok-Location.jpg)](/wiki/File:LakeVostok-
Location.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:LakeVostok-Location.jpg "Enlarge")

The location of Vostok Station in Antarctica

The lowest natural temperature ever directly recorded at ground level on
[Earth](/wiki/Earth "Earth") is −89.2 °C (−128.6 °F; 184.0 K) at the Soviet
[Vostok Station](/wiki/Vostok_Station "Vostok Station") in
[Antarctica](/wiki/Antarctica "Antarctica") on July 21, 1983 by ground
measurements.

A 2009 study estimated that under exceptional climate conditions similar to
those recorded at Vostok 1983, temperatures higher on the plateau around [Dome
Argus](/wiki/Dome_Argus "Dome Argus") could drop lower than −95 °C (−139 °F;
178 K).[1] On August 10, 2010, satellite observations measured a surface
temperature of −93.2 °C (−135.8 °F; 180.0 K) at 81.8°S 59.3°E, along a ridge
between Dome Argus and [Dome Fuji](/wiki/Dome_Fuji "Dome Fuji"), at 3,900 m
elevation.[2] The result was reported at the 46th annual meeting of the
[American Geophysical Union](/wiki/American_Geophysical_Union "American
Geophysical Union") in San Francisco, in December 2013; it is a provisional
figure, and may be subject to revision.[3]

The value may not be listed as the record lowest temperature as it was
measured by [remote sensing](/wiki/Remote_sensing "Remote sensing") satellites
and not by ground-based [thermometers](/wiki/Thermometer "Thermometer"),
unlike the 1983 record.[4] The temperature announced reflects that of the ice
surface, while the Vostok readings measured the air above the ice, and so the
two are not directly comparable. However, it is most likely that the real
temperature on the site was lower than that recorded at Vostok.[3]

## Contents

[hide]

  * 1 Historical progression
  * 2 Laboratory cooling
    * 2.1 Early
    * 2.2 Modern
  * 3 See also
  * 4 References
  * 5 External links

## Historical
progression[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lowest_temperature_recorded_on_Earth&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Historical progression")]

On January 21, 1838 a recording was made by the Russian merchant Neverov in
[Yakutsk](/wiki/Yakutsk "Yakutsk"), of −60 °C (−76 °F; 213 K).[5] On January
15, 1885 H. Wild reported that a temperature of −68 °C (−90 °F; 205 K) was
noted in [Verkhoyansk](/wiki/Verkhoyansk "Verkhoyansk").[5] A later
measurement at the same place in February 1892 was reported as −69.8 °C (−93.6
°F; 203.3 K). Soviet researchers later announced a recording of −67.7 °C
(−89.9 °F; 205.5 K) in February 1933 at [Oymyakon](/wiki/Oymyakon "Oymyakon"),
about 650 km (400 mi) to the south-east of Verkhoyansk; this measurement was
reported by Soviet texts through the 1940s as a record low, with the previous
measurement from Verkhoyansk retroactively adjusted to −67.6 °C (−89.7 °F;
205.6 K).[6]

The next reliable measurement was made during the 1957 season at the
[Amundsen–Scott South Pole
Station](/wiki/Amundsen%E2%80%93Scott_South_Pole_Station "Amundsen–Scott South
Pole Station") in [Antarctica](/wiki/Antarctica "Antarctica"), yielding −73.6
°C (−100.5 °F; 199.6 K) on May 11 and −74.5 °C (−102.1 °F; 198.7 K) on
September 17.[5] A subsequent measurement of −88.3 °C (−126.9 °F; 184.8 K), on
August 24, 1960, held the record until a temperature of −89.2 °C (−128.6 °F;
184.0 K) was measured at the Soviet [Vostok Station](/wiki/Vostok_Station
"Vostok Station"), on the [Antarctic Plateau](/wiki/Antarctic_Plateau
"Antarctic Plateau"), on July 21, 1983.[7] This remains the record for a
directly recorded temperature.

## Laboratory
cooling[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lowest_temperature_recorded_on_Earth&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Laboratory cooling")]

For more details on this topic, see [Absolute zero §
History](/wiki/Absolute_zero#History "Absolute zero").

###
Early[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lowest_temperature_recorded_on_Earth&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Early")]

In 1904 Dutch scientist [Heike Kamerlingh Onnes](/wiki/Heike_Kamerlingh_Onnes
"Heike Kamerlingh Onnes") created a special lab in [Leiden](/wiki/Leiden
"Leiden") with the aim of producing [liquid helium](/wiki/Liquid_helium
"Liquid helium"). In 1908 he managed to lower the temperature to less than
−269 °C (-452.2 F, 4 K), which is less than four degrees above [absolute
zero](/wiki/Absolute_zero "Absolute zero"). Only in this exceptionally cold
state will helium liquefy, the boiling point of helium being at −268.94 °C
(-452.092 F). Kamerlingh Onnes received a [Nobel Prize](/wiki/Nobel_Prize
"Nobel Prize") for his achievement.[8]

Onnes' method relied upon depressurising the subject gases, causing them to
cool by [adiabatic cooling](/wiki/Adiabatic_cooling "Adiabatic
cooling").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] This follows from the first law of
thermodynamics;

Δ U = Δ Q − Δ W {\displaystyle \Delta U=\Delta Q-\Delta W} ![\\Delta U=\\Delta
Q-\\Delta
W](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/eb42dc99e2fb6fd5c896a5ccd8e3e5af6f548683)

where _U_ = [internal energy](/wiki/Internal_energy "Internal energy"), _Q_ =
[heat](/wiki/Heat "Heat") added to the system, _W_ =
[work](/wiki/Work_\(thermodynamics\) "Work \(thermodynamics\)") done by the
system.

Consider a gas in a box of set volume. If the pressure in the box is higher
than atmospheric pressure, then upon opening the box our gas will do work on
the surrounding atmosphere to expand. As this expansion is
[adiabatic](/wiki/Adiabatic_process "Adiabatic process") and the gas has done
work

Δ Q = 0 {\displaystyle \Delta Q=0} ![\\Delta
Q=0](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ece3f71eee6ecc378b46624fc42f715f0dab970f)

Δ W > 0 {\displaystyle \Delta W>0} ![\\Delta
W>0](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/fa0e5652b61c717fbbde24bd4b62f6b288466cf7)

⇒ Δ U < 0 {\displaystyle \Rightarrow \Delta U<0} ![\\Rightarrow \\Delta
U<0](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c43f756228984810e101843b9cd80b02ba040635)

Now as the internal energy has decreased, so has the temperature.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

###
Modern[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lowest_temperature_recorded_on_Earth&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Modern")]

As of November 2000, [nuclear spin](/wiki/Nuclear_spin "Nuclear spin")
temperatures below 100 pK were reported for an experiment at the [Helsinki
University of Technology](/wiki/Helsinki_University_of_Technology "Helsinki
University of Technology") Low Temperature Lab. However, this was the
temperature of one particular type of motion—a quantum property called nuclear
spin—not the overall average thermodynamic temperature for all possible
degrees of freedom.[9] At such low temperatures, the concept of
"[temperature](/wiki/Temperature "Temperature")" becomes multifaceted since
molecular motion cannot be assumed to average out across degrees of
freedom.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The corresponding peak emission will be in
radio waves, rather than in the familiar infrared, so it is very inefficiently
absorbed by neighboring atoms, making it difficult to reach thermal
equilibrium.

Low Temperature Laboratory recorded a record low temperature of 100
[pK](/wiki/1_E-12_K "1 E-12 K"), or 1.0 × 10−10 K in 1999.[10]

The current apparatus for achieving low temperatures has two stages. The first
utilizes a [helium dilution refrigerator](/wiki/Dilution_refrigerator
"Dilution refrigerator") to get to temperatures of millikelvins, then the next
stage uses [adiabatic nuclear demagnetisation](/wiki/Adiabatic_demagnetization
"Adiabatic demagnetization") to reach picokelvins.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Extremely low temperatures are useful for observation of [quantum
mechanical](/wiki/Quantum_mechanic "Quantum mechanic") phases of matter such
as [superfluids](/wiki/Superfluid "Superfluid") and [Bose-Einstein
condensates](/wiki/Bose-Einstein_condensate "Bose-Einstein condensate"), which
would be disrupted by thermal motion.

qa.question: where was the lowest temperature ever recorded on earth

triviaqa_42266_11.Query Analysis: The query asks for the location where the lowest temperature ever recorded on Earth was measured.
